name: youtube-playlistd-depracated
readme_content:
# YouTube Playlist Daemon

## Overview
YouTube Playlist Daemon is a tool designed to serve as a bridge between YouTube playlists and large language models like ChatGPT. It enables efficient use of playlist data in applications such as RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), content curation, and educational platforms.

## Motivation and Use Cases
1. **Language Model Integration**: Facilitates the integration of YouTube playlist data into language models for enhanced content retrieval and processing.
2. **Playlist Management Outside YouTube**: Simplifies tracking and managing educational or curated content, useful for bloggers and educators.
3. **Educational Tool**: Showcases the application development process using conversational AI, potentially including a feature to view the development chat.

## Features
- Import playlists from YouTube channels or JSON files.
- Manage playlists: add, delete, and update content.
- Search within playlists.
- API endpoints to fetch playlist details.

## Requirements

- Docker
- Docker Compose

## Setup

1. Clone this repository.
2. Build and run the Docker containers: `docker-compose up --build`

The application will be available at `http://localhost:8000`.

## Google API Setup

This application uses the YouTube Data API v3 to import playlists from YouTube channels. To use this feature, you need to set up Google API credentials and authenticate the application.

### Obtaining Google API Credentials

1. Go to the [Google Cloud Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/).
2. Create a new project.
3. Enable the YouTube Data API v3 for your project.
4. Create credentials for a desktop application. This will give you a client ID and client secret.
5. Download the credentials and save them in a file named `client_secrets.json` in the root directory of this project.

### Authenticating the Application

The first time you run the application, it will attempt to authenticate with Google's API using the credentials in the `client_secrets.json` file. You will be prompted to log in to your Google account and grant the application access to your YouTube data. Once you do this, an access token will be generated and saved in a file named `token.pickle` in the root directory of this project. This token will be used for future requests to the API.

If the access token expires, the application will automatically use the refresh token to obtain a new one. If the `token.pickle` file is deleted, you will need to re-authenticate the application.

## API Usage

A Swagger UI available is available at the `/docs` endpoint. For example, if the server is running on `localhost:8000`, the Swagger UI will be available at `localhost:8000/docs`. The OpenAPI schema is available at `/openapi.json` and `/openapi.yml`. For example, if the server is running on `localhost:8000`, the OpenAPI schema will be available at `localhost:8000/openapi.json` and `localhost:8000/openapi.yml`.

## API Endpoints

### Import Playlists from a YouTube Channel
- **Endpoint**: `/import-playlists/`
- **Method**: POST
- **Description**: Imports playlists from a specified YouTube channel into Redis.
- **Parameters**: `channel_id` (string) - The ID of the YouTube channel.
- **Returns**: Success message upon successful import.

### Import Playlists from JSON File
- **Endpoint**: `/import-json-playlists/`
- **Method**: POST
- **Description**: Imports playlists from a provided JSON file into Redis.
- **RequestBody**: A file containing JSON data of playlists.
- **Returns**: Success message after importing.

### Delete a Playlist
- **Endpoint**: `/playlist/{playlist_id}`
- **Method**: DELETE
- **Description**: Deletes a specified playlist from Redis.
- **Parameters**: `playlist_id` (string) - The ID of the playlist to be deleted.
- **Returns**: The deleted playlist data or an error message.

### Add Video to Playlist
- **Endpoint**: `/playlist/{playlist_id}/video/`
- **Method**: POST
- **Description**: Adds a video to a specified playlist.
- **Parameters**: `playlist_id` (string) - The ID of the playlist.
- **RequestBody**: `Video` object containing video details.
- **Returns**: Updated playlist with the new video.

### Delete Video from Playlist
- **Endpoint**: `/playlist/{playlist_id}/video/{video_id}`
- **Method**: DELETE
- **Description**: Removes a video from a specified playlist.
- **Parameters**: 
   - `playlist_id` (string) - The playlist ID.
   - `video_id` (string) - The ID of the video to be removed.
- **Returns**: Updated playlist data or an error message.

### Create a New Playlist
- **Endpoint**: `/playlist/`
- **Method**: POST
- **Description**: Creates a new playlist in Redis.
- **RequestBody**: `Playlist` object with playlist details.
- **Returns**: The created playlist data.

### Search Playlists
- **Endpoint**: `/search/`
- **Method**: GET
- **Description**: Searches for playlists containing the query in their title.
- **Parameters**: `query` (string) - The search query.
- **Returns**: List of playlists matching the query.

### Retrieve a Specific Playlist
- **Endpoint**: `/playlist/{playlist_id}`
- **Method**: GET
- **Description**: Fetches details of a specific playlist.
- **Parameters**: `playlist_id` (string) - The ID of the playlist.
- **Returns**: Playlist data or an error message.

### Retrieve All Playlists
- **Endpoint**: `/playlists/`
- **Method**: GET
- **Description**: Returns all playlists stored in Redis.
- **Parameters**: 
   - `exclude_videos` (boolean) - Option to exclude video details.
   - `exclude_video_desc` (boolean) - Option to exclude video descriptions.
- **Returns**: List of all playlists.

### Download Playlists as JSON

- **Endpoint**: `/download_as_json/`
- **Method**: GET
- **Description**: Downloads all playlists as a JSON file.
- **Returns**: JSON file containing all playlists.

## Example

To import the playlists from my YouTube channel [queelius](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCYNVzb35O7e2GBICAYfOXDg), which has a channel ID of `UC8butISFwT-Wl7EV0hUK0BQ`, send a POST request to the `/import-playlists/` endpoint with the channel ID as a parameter.

```bash
curl -X POST "http://localhost:8000/import-playlists/" -H "accept: application/json" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d "{\"channel_id\":\"UC8butISFwT-Wl7EV0hUK0BQ\"}"
```

## Future Work

- **Vector Database Integration**: To assist with RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), integrate a vector database.
- **Function Calling**: Implement standard interfaces for LMs (language models) to use this as a tool.
- **Better Search**: Implement a more robust search algorithm using RediSearch.
- **Development Process**: Post the the ChatGPT chat history that lead to the development of this tool.

## Contribution

I am open to contributions and suggestions. Please open an issue or pull request if you have any ideas.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.

name: algebraic_random_elements
description: Implementation of algebraic random elements. See the paper.
readme_content:
# Random process concept
An example of a random process is a time series or an ngram model.
An object type `W` models this concept if it provides the signature

```cpp
    template <urbg U>    
    W::sample(U &) -> value_type<W>
```

where `U` models the concept of a uniform random bit generator.

The semantics of objects of type `W` are that it models a sequence of random
elements `{W[t]}`, which may be correlated, such that the `k`-th
random element `W[k]` is given by the `k`-th invokation of the `sample`
procedure on a particular object of type `W`.

We say random elements since it may be a random variable, random vector,
or more complicated structures like a random set, matrix, or compound algebraic
type like, like a random hash function.

## Independent random elements

Suppose a random process `{W[t]}` consists of independent and uncorreated random
elements.
Furthermore, suppose the elements of `{W[t]}` are also identitically
distributed.

Then, we are in the classical space of independently and identically distributed
random elements (i.i.d.), which simplifies things significantly.

A uniform random bit generator is one of the most important
types of i.i.d. random processes since they may be used to generate other
kinds of random processes, which is why the `sample` procedure accepts an
object of type `U` as an argument.

Note: any random process may be modeled as an independent compound random
element type through a simple transformation.

There are additional functions on i.i.d. random elements that may be more
meaningfully or more simply defined, such as expectation:

```cpp
    template <typename G>
    auto expect(W, G)
```

# Functions of random processes

We provide a generic interface to random elements that allows for various
compositions, many of which are closed under some operation set.

# Limits

We also provide *limiting* distributions, i.e., if we take the limit of a sum of
independent random vectors, by the central limit theorem the result is a
normally distributed random vector.







# Random elements

The *sample space* of an experiment is the set of mutually exclusive *outcomes*
that may be observed.
Sets of outcomes are denoted *events* where an event that contains one outcome
is denoted an *elementary event* and the event containing all outcomes is the
sample space.

The set of all possible events is a sigma-algebra.
Suppose the sample space is `X`.
A sigma-algebra on `X` is a set `A` of subsets of `X` that satisfies
the following conditions:

1. `A` includes `X`, the sample space.
2. `A` includes `{}`, the empty set.
3. `A` is *closed* under countable unions, intersections, and complements.

If these conditions are met, the pair `(X, A)` denotes a measureable space.

Suppose the outcome of the experiment is *uncertain*.
Any event `E` in `A` that includes the outcome has been satisfied by the
experment.
Let `P : A -> [0,1]` be a countably additive function that maps events to
*probabilities*.
The triple `(X, A, P)` defines a *probability space*.
The relative frequency of any event `E` in `A` converges to probability `P(E)`
as the number of times the experiment is repeated goes to infinity.

# Random variables
A random variable is a measurable function `W : X -> Y` from outcomes `X` to
measurable space `Y`.
The probability that `W` realizes some measureable subset `S` of `Y` is given by
`P(W in S) = P({w in X | W(w) in S})`.

As a random variable, normally the measurable space `Y` is at minimum a semi-
ring (closed under multiplication and summation), which makes it possible to
define concepts like expected value and variance.

We model the random elements from a generative perspective, and thus the
computational basis is the ability to generate values that are independent
realizations of the random element.

However, every random element must also, at least implicitly, have a well-
defined probability distribution function.

From the generative model, we may estimate the pdf, but for computational
efficiency it may also be provided with the signature

```cpp
    pdf(W) -> (value_type<W> -> R)
```
where `R` models the concept of a non-negative continuous number.

## Functions of random variables

Observe that a function of random process sampled multiple times may be used
to model some other more complicated random process.


We provide a generic interface to random variables that allows for various
compositions of random variables, many of which are closed under some operation
set.

## Limits

We also provide *limiting* distributions, i.e., if we take the limit of a sum of
random variables, by the central limit theorem the result is a normal random
variable.

## Random vectors: jointly distributed random variables

More complicated mathematical structures may be of interest, such as a
random vector, random set, random matrix, or more generally random element.
The most popular case is given by the concept of a random vector, which is just
`n` random variables `(W_1, ..., W_n)` which may be correlated.

name: packed_data
readme_content:
Packed containers {#mainpage}
=================
A packed container of type `X`, denoted by `P(X)`, *packs* value types of type
`X` into a container, where each value is an object with arbitrary bit alignment
such that no bits are wasted within the container.

The way the data values of type `X` are packed into the container is handled by
a codec, an object type that implements the concept of a [Codec](CODEC_CONCEPT.md).

Typically, the value type `X` has other "native" object types which are byte
aligned and thus can have a machine
, e.g., in C++ we have primitive object types like `int` and `double`,
and compound object types like a class that composes multiple f

A data structure `P(X)` implements a packed container of type `X` if the
following conditions are satisfied:

1. `P(X)` is a [RegularType](regular_type).
2. `P(X)` has an [Iterator](iterator) that permits element traversal.
3. `P(X)` has accessors that allows retrieving a *packed element* (i.e., it has
    not been decoded to an object of)



A fixed-width packed array of type `X` is a packed array of type `X` where all
the values of type `X` have codes that are the same width. A general approach
to allowing these elements to be indexable in constant time (O(1) random access)
is to make each index map to a row in a bit matrix of fixed width, where each
row stores the code for the value.

Index | Element | Encoding
----- | ------- | ---------
`0`   | `x_1`   | `{0,1}^k`
`1`   | `x_2`   | `{0,1}^k`
`2`   | `x_3`   | `{0,1}^k`

Read more about packed containers [here](packed_containers.pdf).

## Variable-length packed array

A variable-length packed array of type `X` is a packed array where elements
of type `X` have arbitirary-length encodings. A general approach to allowing
these elements to be indexable in constant time (O(1) random access) is to
make each index map to a row in a bit matrix of fixed width, where each row
is a pointer to a bit string.

If constant write times are not necessary, then the pointer may be into a
large contiguous range of bits such that no space is wasted on alignment issues.

Index | Element | Bit Address | Encoding
----- | ------- | ----------- | --------
0     | x1      | {0,1}^k     | {0,1}^n1
1     | x2      | {0,1}^k     | {0,1}^n2
2     | x3      | {0,1}^k     | {0,1}^n3

If the packed array is immutable, then the entire data underlying the packed
array can be one contiguous range of bits, where padding is only necessary
for the last byte.

name: series_system_estimation_from_masked_system_failure_time_samples
readme_content:
# Estimating series systems from samples with masked system failure times

Suppose we have a population of similar systems and we are interested in their
lifetime properties. 

Assumption: Two randomly chosen subsets of the same size generally have similiar
empirical distributions and converge to the same distribution as the sample size
increases, i.e., the lifetimes of the systems are *independently and identically
distributed* (iid).

If the only information we have about population is given by a sample of `n`
system lifetimes, then we may model each point in the sample as having an
random lifetime `T(j)` for `j=1,...,n` where each `T(j)` is iid and greater than
zero. We may estimate properties that are only a function of the system
lifetime, such as the mean time to failure.

Most systems are more complex than just 'having a lifetime' and thus have
multiple observable properties. One of the simplest structures is a series
system, where the system is modelled as `m` independent components each with an
uncertain lifetime. The random lifetime of the `j-th` component of the `k-th`
system in a sample is denoted by `T(j,k)`

The maximum information about the `j-th`system in a sample is then given by
observing each of the `m` component lifetimes, `T(j,1), ..., T(j,m)`, and the
system lifetime is a function of the `m` component lifetimes,
    `T(j) = min{T(j,1), ..., T(j,m)}`.

*We may ask other questions about the system since we have more information.*

The maximum information in a sample of `n` system lifetimes is then given by
a sample of `n` vectors of size `m`. The sample may now be represented as a
matrix of `n` rows and `m` columns.

Often, we cannot observe all the propoerties of the system. For instance, in a
series system we may only be able to observe the system for a fixed unit of
time `t`, which may result in situations where, if the system has no failed, we
only know that `T(j,1) > t, ..., T(j, m) > t`, or if the system has failed at
time `t`, we may only know the component lifetimes of some subset of the `m`
components and we only know that the remaining have uncertain lifetimes greater
than `t`.

There is another type of uncertainty we are interested in. Often, we are able
to observe some properties of a system that we know are functions of some other
unobserved parts of the system. For instance, in a series system, if we are only
able to observe the system lifetime T(j) but none of the component lifetimes,
we say that `T(j,1),...,T(j,m)` are **latent** random variables.

In the previous example, we did not have enough information to estimate the
properties of the components. In this case, we may as well forget the serial
structure and model it as a point system as before. However, there are other
things that may be observed about the series system.

We are particularly interested in **masked system failure times**, where we
observe the system lifetime and also observe some subset of the components
that caused, or likely caused, the failure. That is to say, we observe something
like the following two properties:

1. For the `j-th` system, we observed that it failed at time `t`. So, we know that
one of the components has a lifetime `t` and the remaining components have a
lifetime greater than `t`.

2. For system `j`, we also observed that one of the components in some subset `C`
of `{1,..,m}` failed at time `t`. If `C = {1,...,m}` then this tells us nothing.
If `|C| = 1` this tells us exactly which component failed. This is the maximum
information possible given samples of this kind, but note that it is still not
as much information as knowing the lifetimes of all `m` components.

Thus, samples take the form:
```
{
    T(1),{1,3},
    T(2),{1,2},
    T(3),{2,3,4}
}
```

name: univeral_coders
readme_content:
# Generic prefix-free coders

The library of coders are separated into two different
conceptual categories, dictionary coders and universal
coders.

## Dictionary coders

Assume that

$$
  X_i \sim f_{\theta}
$$

and we generate the i.i.d. process

$$
  X_1 X_2 \cdots X_n.
$$

Then, there is some dictionary coder \f$E\f$ that is
expected to optimally compress the sequence, i.e.,

$$
  \mathrm{length}(E(X_1 X_2 \cdots X_n)) = n\times \mathrm{entropy}(X).
$$

The canoncial example is given by Huffman codes.
In Huffman codes, in general we nearly obtain optimality,
but there is a slight overhead as a result of each
code needing to be a whole number of bits.

However, if we encode, say, the sequence as a
set of bigrams,

$$
  (X_1 X_2) (X_3 X_4) \cdots (X_{n-1} X_n)
$$

in which the bigrams have the probabilities

$$
  P(X_{j-1},X_j) = P(X_{j-1})P(X_j|X_{j-1})
$$

for \f$j=2,\ldots,n\f$.

We may obtain a result that is closer to the Shannon
lower-bound, since the overhead mentioned previously only
occurs at the level of the bigram sequence, which is
half the size of the unigram sequence.

Additionally, observe that if \f$X_1 X_2 \cdots X_n\f$ are
not independent, then the bigram sequence above generally
results in better compression in a different way, since
the probabilities include information in the correlations
that may occur in a sequences of up to 2 symbols.
We may, of course, extend this to coding \f$k\f$-grams.
If \f$X_1 X_2 \cdots X_n\f$ are i.i.d., then
\f$P(X_{j-1},X_j) = P(X_{j-1})P(X_j)\f$.

## Universal prefix-free coders

Universal prefix-free coders are optimal or
near-optimal for different families of probability
distributions and may work over an infinite
alphabet, e.g., natural numbers.

A common Universal coder is the geometric
coder, where if $X_i \sim \mathrm{GEO}(p)$,
then the geometric coder is (near) optimal.

\ref @universal_codes "Universal coder"
[Univeral coder](@ref universalcode)
